0.text:
Hi guys! Let's talk about something that bugs
me a little. Well, a lot. A lottle?

4.text:
A while ago I was talking to a dear friend
of mine, and she was dropping the following line.

8.text: I don't really care about politics.

12.text:
I don't understand people who say that. Well
okay, yes I do.

16.text:
Politicians are weird, old, white cis dudes
most of the time and political issues can

21.text:
seem very dry and unimportant or important,
but very, very, very boring to you.

28.text:
So you just wade through this kind of grey
mud of "I should probably kind of be invested

34.text: in this, but I'm just really not".

36.text:
But here's why you really should care about
politics.

44.text:
Politics are what holds us together, and also
what divides us.

51.text:
Taking a stand against the lawmakers that
fuck up your country is important.

54.text:
And for that you don't have to be involved
in a party. You don't have to enroll in the

59.text:
political debate teams at your uni.
In fact, although you really should, you don't

63.text:
even have to go out into the streets to rally
against the latest fucked up policy that your

70.text:
What you really should do though, is get informed.
Read on what the parties promise, knowing

75.text:
that they probably won't keep all of their
promises anyway,

77.text:
read up on how your country's voting system,
inform your friends of what you've learned.

82.text:
Ask friends for help, discuss politics. Don't
be afraid to ask questions! And don't be afraid

87.text: to teach others what you've already learned.

89.text:
Every little bit is enough, as long as you're
trying!

92.text:
You don't have to care about politician's
faces or even names, you don't have to care

97.text:
what member has been in which party since
when, but you should pay attention to who

102.text:
moves what in the country that you're living
in, or that you have voting power in.

105.text:
Learn how deeply rooted everything is in history,
learn how history has been shaped by bad politics

111.text:
and, way less often, good politics.
Form opinions on what you think has to change

118.text:
Yes, that vote will most likely go to the
lesser of two or more evils, and not to the

123.text:
greatest party ever, but it's still important,
it's still your vote, and it's your voice!

128.text:
What especially baffles me is that that friend
who said that is a feminist.

132.text:
Intersectional feminism has so much to do
with politics, especially if we're talking

136.text:
equal rights for the LGBTQ community or people
of colour. This change HAS to come from our

141.text:
lawmakers just as much as it has to come
from within our society. Politics are IMPORTANT.

148.text:
That said, I'm not a political whiz myself,
most political debates bore me to death, but

152.text:
that is part of my own personal limits and
it's okay to have them, as long as you try

158.text: and as long as you're invested somehow - you have a voice, and you use that voice!

164.text:
I find it really sad and discouraging that
the voter participation of people my age is

169.text:
so incredibly low.
We can change our future, and although we're

174.text:
not represented in the government yet, there's
no way we can get there if we don't cast our

179.text:
vote whenever we can! We have a voice, so
let's speak up!

184.text:
Okay, that was a bit of a different programme
today, but this channel wouldn't be a complete

189.text:
picture of me if it didn't include political
rants from time to time.
